content:
- The alerts are displayed for the current day by default.
- The user can view the alerts in a selected date range.
- The user can see the total amount of alerts detected in the selected date range and can distinguish between the urgency level of the alerts.
- The user can filter the alerts by their type, category, description.
- The user can define alerts by requesting it from the hub team. The alert can be defined with respect to the hierarchy: Alert Type > Alert Category > Alert Description.
- The user can see the status of the alerts, and resolve the pending ones.
- The user can understand why the alert is detected from its description and the reference columns.

metadata.title: Bella Canvas User Stories

content:
- The user can understand why the alert is detected from its description and the reference columns.
- The user can understand the reason of the detected alert by clicking on the “go to link” button at the end of each alert record row. The user can go to the related screen to take the required action, by filtering the specific alerted record on the new screen.The go-to-links can be configured with respect to the client’s needs.
- The user can define alert threshold inputs from the parameter configuration screens, for the alerts related with Store RPL Orders and Targets. The related parameters are: Target Alert Threshold & Order Alert Threshold
- The user can see the critical alerts for dc and store replenishment and go to the screens via the go-to links, and verify that these records’ orders have not been automatically sent. The user first needs to review these alerts, take required action, acknowledge the alert from the alert screen, and approve the order quantity later on.

metadata.title: Bella Canvas User Stories

content:
quired action, acknowledge the alert from the alert screen, and approve the order quantity later on.
- The user can not access the alerts of all times. The historic alerts are maintained periodically. The alerts are maintained and cleaned periodically, by a predefined schedule with the UI team.
- The user can pause or deactivate an alert by communicating with the hub team.
- The alerts can be filtered from the filter icon.

Backlog user stories:

- Alerts can be detected on a defined source.

## Promo Plan

Covered user stories:

- The user can define a promotion for the predefined promo types, by uploading csv.
- The user can choose to upload buy quantity or directly just upload the promotion list.
- The user can edit the start-end dates of the promos.
- The user can delete a created promo.
- The defined upcoming promotion list can be observed from the Control Tower / promo section.

Backlog user stories:

metadata.title: Bella Canvas User Stories

content:
coming promotion list can be observed from the Control Tower / promo section.

Backlog user stories:

- The user can define new promotion types from a new tab.
- The user can see the existing promotion records in the system.
- The user can the defined promotions on a gantt chart / on a calendar. (can use the promotion solution here - details to be added)

## Manual Order Management

Covered user stories:Backlog user stories:

metadata.title: Bella Canvas User Stories

content:
> Info: This page shows the general flow of DC Replenishment Orders.

## Basics

| What? this screen holds | This page provides all the necessary details to review and edit the Purchase Order suggestions. |
| --- | --- |
| How? this screen works | DC replenishment is calculated based on supplier availability, warehouse capacity limits, and store order demand estimations. The resulting order suggestion is the Purchase Order (PO) suggestion, which is reviewed by the users through the screen workflow. |
| Why? should I use this | This page helps users review, adjust, and improve suggested POs to better prepare for the upcoming store order demand. |

## Inventory Planning Features

The Inventory Planning section offers key features to help users filter and manage DC-level replenishment data, apply quick constraints, perform bulk actions, and review past sales trends, supporting better forecasting and decision-making.

DC Replenishment Screen (in editable view)

metadata.title: Bella Canvas Inventory Planning (DC RPL Orders) - User Guide

content:
ends, supporting better forecasting and decision-making.

DC Replenishment Screen (in editable view)

Filter Panel:Allows users to apply filters such as Aggregations, Unitto refine the displayed data.

Quick Filters:Users can quickly filter records based on pre-defined quick filters to better and effectively navigate the order results.

noteQuick filters such as Max Constraint, Min Constraint, PO Expedite, Buy Optimization, and Excess Inventory arenot defaultquick filters. The quick filters can vary depending on the configurations and specific needs.

Quick filters such as Max Constraint, Min Constraint, PO Expedite, Buy Optimization, and Excess Inventory arenot defaultquick filters. The quick filters can vary depending on the configurations and specific needs.

Bulk Action & Order Management Panel:Contains options for performing bulk actions, including approve, cancel, edit, release orders, and download data.

metadata.title: Bella Canvas Inventory Planning (DC RPL Orders) - User Guide

content:
ons for performing bulk actions, including approve, cancel, edit, release orders, and download data.

Historical Transactions Chart:Clicking the chart icon in the Actions column opens the related record’s historical sales and order trends for better decision-making.

Inventory Planning - Order ReviewThis section explains how to work with the DC Replenishment table, including how to filter records, change the unit view, show or hide columns, download data, and update multiple rows at once. These features help users review and manage order suggestions at the DC level more efficiently.

metadata.title: Bella Canvas Inventory Planning (DC RPL Orders) - User Guide

content:
nce. These features help users review and manage order suggestions at the DC level more efficiently.

- Records can be filtered based on product and store attributes using the filter pane.Items such as Source Code, Sales Channel, Product Hierarchy, and Supplier can be selected from the Aggregations option. The "Unit" button allows changing the displayed unit between currency and quantity. If the currency is selected, the order grid is displayed with inventory cost.Columns can be shown or hidden using the eye icon.Applied filters can be cleared using the filter-out icon.The download option is available for saving the data. Also, multiple rows can be selected to modify purchase order values and take release-related actions on them.The Order Status column displays the progress of each order, making it easy for users to see whether an order is pending review, ready for release, or already completed.

The order release management statuses and available actions can be summarized as:

metadata.title: Bella Canvas Inventory Planning (DC RPL Orders) - User Guide

content:
lready completed.

The order release management statuses and available actions can be summarized as:

| Status | Editable | Cancellable | Approvable | Releasable |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Waiting for Review | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ❌ |
| Order Reviewed | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ❌ |
| Waiting For Release | ❌ | ✅ | ❌ | ✅ |
| Order Released | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ |
| Order Cancelled | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ |

How to Edit an OrderThe suggested purchase orders can be edited by the users.

- To begin, select the relevant items to enable the editable view from the Aggregations menu. Please follow the instructions in the “See Details To Edit” info section.

metadata.title: Bella Canvas Inventory Planning (DC RPL Orders) - User Guide

content:
rom the Aggregations menu. Please follow the instructions in the “See Details To Edit” info section.

> Info: See Details to EditIn order to enable the editable view on the grid, three specific dimensions should be selected from the Aggregation pane.The details on the tooltip should be followed to activate the editable workflow.Product Aggregation (e.g., Product Code or Description)Supplier Aggregation (e.g., Supplier Code or Description)Warehouse Aggregation (e.g., Warehouse Code or Description)Editing actions will remain inaccessible unless the specified criteria are met on the aggregations.

metadata.title: Bella Canvas Inventory Planning (DC RPL Orders) - User Guide

content:
)Editing actions will remain inaccessible unless the specified criteria are met on the aggregations.

- Once selected, users can edit any cell by clicking on it and updating the PO suggestion as needed.
- To retain the edited value, the record must be saved. Upon completion of the save operation, the status will automatically update from “Waiting for Review” to “Order Reviewed”. This step enables continued editing at a later stage.
- Once the changes are confirmed, users may approve the edited data, thereby updating the status to “Waiting for Release”. Note that this approval is final and cannot be reversed.
- If necessary, the user may cancel the order, which will update the status to “Order Canceled”. This action is final and cannot be reversed.

metadata.title: Bella Canvas Inventory Planning (DC RPL Orders) - User Guide

content:
rder, which will update the status to “Order Canceled”. This action is final and cannot be reversed.

How to Release an OrderOnce the order data is reviewed and approved, the next step is to finalize and release it. In this section, it is explained how to release approved orders, confirm quantities, and optionally perform the release from higher aggregation levels for bulk processing.

- The user can select the approved orders and proceed with the release with the Release Order button on any aggregation level.
- During the confirmation step, the user may review the counts and total order amounts for both approved and unapproved orders through the released order summary pop-up.
- Once the release is confirmed, only the approved orders will be processed, and their status will change to "Order Released".
- If required, users may also release orders from higher hierarchy levels, ensuring that all orders with releasable statuses within the hierarchy are processed accordingly.

metadata.title: Bella Canvas Inventory Planning (DC RPL Orders) - User Guide

content:
s, ensuring that all orders with releasable statuses within the hierarchy are processed accordingly.

## The Types of Errors or Warnings

This section provides an overview of the system-generated warnings users may encounter while interacting with charts or editing data. These warnings are categorized as either informative or actionable, depending on whether they simply inform the user or require an action to proceed.

> Note: Actionable Warnings: Displayed when an input or action violates system rules. These warnings require users to make corrections before continuing.

Negative Value Entered:

A warning is displayed when a user enters a negative order value, which is not allowed.

Invalid Text Input:

If a non-numeric order value is entered for an order, it will not be processed.

> Note: Informative Warnings: Used to inform users about the system state or potential limitations. These warnings do not block the workflow but help maintain awareness.

metadata.title: Bella Canvas Inventory Planning (DC RPL Orders) - User Guide

content:
tate or potential limitations. These warnings do not block the workflow but help maintain awareness.

No Approved Orders Available for Release:

If there are no approved results in the selected hierarchy, the order cannot be released. Ensure that the orders are approved before proceeding with the release. If there are no eligible order statuses to be released in the selection, the Release Order summary will display “0” Approved records and order totals.

Approving Orders:

To approve orders, be aware that only orders with the statuses Waiting for Review and Order Reviewed will be approved, and this action cannot be undone.

Cancel Orders:

To cancel orders, be aware that only orders with the statuses Waiting for Review, Order Reviewed, and Waiting for Release will be cancelled, and this action cannot be undone.

Sufficient Stock:

The inventory level is sufficient to meet demand, preventing shortages. It is displayed in green to indicate a stable status.

Understock:

metadata.title: Bella Canvas Inventory Planning (DC RPL Orders) - User Guide

content:
eet demand, preventing shortages. It is displayed in green to indicate a stable status.

Understock:

The inventory level is too low to meet demand, signaling a potential shortage. It is displayed in red to highlight a critical condition.

## Summary

### Bell Canvas Project Team Introduction

### The team met to discuss the Bella Canvas project, with Kevin introducing the full team including Luis,

metadata.title: Discovery & Requirement Gathering

content:
e team met to discuss the Bella Canvas project, with Kevin introducing the full team including Luis,

Utku, Talha, and Dan. Christina and Patrice explained that Annie would be joining to shadow them, focusing on design, while the full team discussed their time zones, with members spread across East Coast, Central, Pacific, and Turkey (UTC+3). The meeting served as an introductory session to align the team and establish communication across different time zones, with the project currently in its design phase.

### Data Integration for Supply Network

metadata.title: Discovery & Requirement Gathering

content:
time zones, with the project currently in its design phase.

### Data Integration for Supply Network

### The team discussed the data integration project with Bella, focusing on their complex supply network and tiered distribution model. Kevin outlined the project's goals, including developing a seasonal demand forecast and optimizing inventory flow. The team agreed to start at a high level, understanding the current process and business model, before diving into specific modules. Patrice emphasized the need for agility in the project, given the constantly changing nature of Bella's business and trade agreements. The conversation ended with a review of a questionnaire to guide future discussions and ensure all aspects of the business are covered.

### Revenue Stream Channel Shift Analysis

metadata.title: Discovery & Requirement Gathering

content:
sions and ensure all aspects of the business are covered.

### Revenue Stream Channel Shift Analysis

### Patrice explained the company's revenue streams, which include a distributor channel (80% of business), direct sales (including e-commerce, craft retailers, white glove accounts, and Amazon), and private label manufacturing. She noted that direct sales have been growing at the expense of distributors over the past two years, with direct now comprising 20-25% of business. The company is expanding into private label manufacturing, including work with a Kpop group, and is developing analytics to track performance across different channels and verticals.

### Bella Canvas Inventory Strategy Review

metadata.title: Discovery & Requirement Gathering

content:
ack performance across different channels and verticals.

### Bella Canvas Inventory Strategy Review

### Patrice and Kevin discussed Bella Canvas's inventory management and assortment strategy. They reviewed the process of analyzing and dropping underperforming products, with Patrice explaining that they aim to reduce the product assortment to around 700 SKUs. The team uses sales data and inventory liability to make decisions on what to drop, and they often offer account recount discounts to help distributors liquidate inventory. Patrice mentioned that they currently accept about 3-4 million dollars worth of RTVs annually, with

closeout sales often occurring at significantly reduced prices. They are working on improving their closeout strategy and have recently started partnering with national discount retailers to move excess inventory.

### Automating Inventory Management System

metadata.title: Discovery & Requirement Gathering

content:
th national discount retailers to move excess inventory.

### Automating Inventory Management System

### The team discussed their inventory management system, which tracks approximately 7,000 SKUs and reviews them monthly. Patrice explained they use a master planning tool that integrates sales performance, transfers, and production data, allowing different teams to make informed decisions. Christina revealed the tool was automated using Python and Cyberquery, though it still requires manual intervention from her or Anika to run. The team agreed the tool is effective but needs to be fully automated to allow non-technical users to access and update it independently.

### Supply Chain Inventory Tracking Tool

metadata.title: Discovery & Requirement Gathering

content:
non-technical users to access and update it independently.

### Supply Chain Inventory Tracking Tool

### The team discussed a supply chain tool designed to track inventory levels and identify items requiring attention, with Patrice explaining it focuses on pushing inventory through manufacturing rather than forecasting. Patrice clarified that the tool helps identify what needs to be chased to meet safety stock targets at the SKU level, showing where production is staged and allowing teams to push specific areas like cutting or sewing. The group agreed to make the tool proprietary, with Christina noting this for follow-up, and Kevin suggested adding forecast data as a potential enhancement to improve its value.

### Inventory Management Team Roles

metadata.title: Discovery & Requirement Gathering

content:
forecast data as a potential enhancement to improve its value.

### Inventory Management Team Roles

### Patrice explained the roles and responsibilities of various teams involved in inventory management, highlighting the inventory planning team as the central group that handles order intake, communicates with sales, and coordinates with production planning. They discussed how the team prioritizes orders, allocates inventory strategically to maximize revenue, and manages allocations for both general population inventory and hold orders for inside sales teams. Kevin asked about how sales costs are determined for distributors, and Patrice explained that there is an automated algorithm for case layering and sort order, with some strategic considerations based on factors like order aging and revenue objectives.

### Forecasting and Inventory Alignment Challenges

metadata.title: Discovery & Requirement Gathering

content:
factors like order aging and revenue objectives.

### Forecasting and Inventory Alignment Challenges

### Patrice explained the company's forecasting and inventory management process, noting that while they receive daily POS data and inventory information from distributors via EDI, there is limited contractual obligation beyond maintaining a certain SKU count. The team discussed challenges with forecasting accuracy, particularly with their top distributor SNS, where there is a significant gap between the company's forecast of 55-60 million units and SNS's forecast of 48 million units. Patrice emphasized the need for better alignment on metrics and clearer agreements regarding inventory calculations, as the current gray areas make collaboration difficult and impact business planning.

### Anaplan's Limitations in Sales Forecasting

### The team discussed the use of

metadata.title: Discovery & Requirement Gathering

content:
usiness planning.

### Anaplan's Limitations in Sales Forecasting

### The team discussed the use of

Anaplan for sales forecasting and inventory management, highlighting gaps in sales velocity and the need for better analysis of missed opportunities due to inventory shortages. Patrice explained that while Anaplan provides valuable insights, manual analysis is still required to correlate inventory levels with sales performance and forecast accuracy. The group acknowledged the limitations of Anaplan in accounting for supply chain issues, such as stockouts, and discussed the importance of having comprehensive data to support recommendations to customers.

### Anaplan Distributor Forecasting Issues

### The team discussed

metadata.title: Discovery & Requirement Gathering

content:
rt recommendations to customers.

### Anaplan Distributor Forecasting Issues

### The team discussed

Anaplan, a forecasting and planning tool that provides customer-level forecasts but currently treats outliers globally rather than by distributor or channel. Patrice explained that while the tool can be adjusted for trends and outliers, it needs manual intervention to review and set bounds, and suggested that the approach might need to be revised given recent changes in distributor market share. Kevin noted that the current system doesn't capture specific distributor trends, particularly for smaller distributors with fewer warehouses, and Patrice mentioned they might need to break out direct business by vertical, especially for craft retailers.

### 2022-2025 Sales Trend Analysis Review

metadata.title: Discovery & Requirement Gathering

content:
ect business by vertical, especially for craft retailers.

### 2022-2025 Sales Trend Analysis Review

### The team reviewed various use case files and forecasting tools, including sales data from 2022-2025, distributor inventory gaps, and trend analysis reports. Patrice emphasized the need for more predictive trend analysis and requested automated reports on color family and silhouette trends to share with creative directors and sales teams. Christina agreed to add these trend analysis reports and a heavyweight deck for executives to the shared files, while Kevin scheduled a follow-up meeting with Christina and Annie to review key findings.

- Kevin: Clarify with Bit Lab and Todd about their need for access to the confidential forecast files.
- Christina: Hand off forecast management responsibilities to Annie.
- Kevin: Demonstrate how Invent can replace the manual forecasting process currently being done with Anaplan.
- Kevin/Luis: Explore automating the forecast process to reduce the time from two days to one day.
- Kevin/Luis: Develop functionality in Invent to automatically calculate lost sales instead of manual gap analysis.
- Kevin/Luis: Create automated recommended buys for distributors based on inventory gaps.
- Kevin/Luis: Develop trend indicators to identify "hot" or "cold" products for quicker reaction.
- Kevin/Luis: Create automated reports showing distributor inventory gaps over time to track improvement.
- Kevin: Provide information on how Invent can improve inventory management metrics beyond the current basic snapshot data.

ation on how Invent can improve inventory management metrics beyond the current basic snapshot data.

- Kevin: Schedule a one-hour meeting with Christina on Friday morning to review Anaplan and other tools.
- Christina: Show Kevin and Annie the Anaplan forecasting system after the meeting to demonstrate how the current forecasting process works.
- Kevin and Luis: Prepare an agenda for the next meeting with Christina.

## Summary

### Forecast and Documentation Priorities

metadata.title: Discovery & Requirement Gathering

content:
n agenda for the next meeting with Christina.

## Summary

### Forecast and Documentation Priorities

### The team discussed the importance of various reports and documentation, with Christina highlighting the forecast as the most critical. Kevin shared that Invent has about 300 employees, with 60-70 in the US and the majority in Turkey. They agreed to start with the forecast report, which Christina explained would be beneficial for both Kevin and Annie. The discussion was cut short due to random messages Christina received about adding people to SharePoint and Invent.

### Confidential Access and Brand Integration

metadata.title: Discovery & Requirement Gathering

content:
eceived about adding people to SharePoint and Invent.

### Confidential Access and Brand Integration

### Christina and Kevin discussed access issues to confidential files, with Christina expressing concerns about unauthorized requests for access without proper authorization. They also reviewed the forecast file, which is partially automated, with Christina explaining its structure and the manual processes involved. Christina provided an overview of style colors, mill codes, and the history of the Bella brand, including the integration of CV (canvas) and BX into the Bella brand.

### Sales Categories and SKU Management

metadata.title: Discovery & Requirement Gathering

content:
the integration of CV (canvas) and BX into the Bella brand.

### Sales Categories and SKU Management

### Christina explained the different sales categories and production groups to Kevin, including the now-defunct BX concept for monthly exclusive items. They discussed the current status of phase-outs, which are internally discontinued but still sold to distributors and available online. Christina clarified that phase-outs are included in the total SKU count of around 7,000, though they are not replenished. They also touched on the ABC classification system for SKUs based on trailing 12-month POS data.

### Historical Demand and Forecast Analysis

metadata.title: Discovery & Requirement Gathering

content:
on system for SKUs based on trailing 12-month POS data.

### Historical Demand and Forecast Analysis

### Kevin and Christina discussed the process of analyzing historical demand data and forecasting future trends. They reviewed how to identify active and new items based on seasons and item statuses. Christina explained the decline in POS data over recent years and shared forecasts for 2025. They also discussed the use of Anaplan for forecasting, including how it generates and validates numbers based on various statistical models and distributor data. Kevin expressed interest in seeing the forecasting process in Anaplan firsthand.

### Inventory Management and Stock Optimization

metadata.title: Discovery & Requirement Gathering

content:
eeing the forecasting process in Anaplan firsthand.

### Inventory Management and Stock Optimization

### Christina and Kevin discussed inventory management and stock availability, focusing on how to assess and improve inventory health. They reviewed a system that tracks distributor stock levels and calculates gaps in availability over 365 days, which helps identify stockout issues. Christina explained that recommended buys are sent to distributors monthly, but compliance is low, and she expressed interest in developing a more comprehensive approach to measure sales loss versus sales velocity. Kevin suggested comparing stockout data to forecasts and other color categories to better understand sales impact.

### Improving Forecasting Efficiency

metadata.title: Discovery & Requirement Gathering

content:
and other color categories to better understand sales impact.

### Improving Forecasting Efficiency

### Christina explained the current process of forecasting, which involves manually reviewing data once a month and takes about two days of focused work. She highlighted the need for a more efficient forecasting method, as the current process is cumbersome and time-consuming. The team discussed the possibility of using sales velocity trends and better indicators to catch hot-selling items more quickly. Kevin suggested that the current forecast already accounts for lost sales, which aligns with Christina's desire for a system that directly shows sales losses.

### Streamlining Forecasting and Inventory Management

metadata.title: Discovery & Requirement Gathering

content:
or a system that directly shows sales losses.

### Streamlining Forecasting and Inventory Management

### Christina and Kevin discussed streamlining the forecasting process to improve efficiency and reduce delays. They agreed on the importance of creating a forecast file, identifying gaps in distributor inventory, and recommending buys to address shortages. Christina explained how Anaplan would be used to integrate forecasts, trigger buy decisions, and coordinate inventory and production planning. They also discussed the need for automation in generating reports and the process of adjusting forecasts based on historical data and market insights.

### Inventory Distribution Gap Analysis

metadata.title: Discovery & Requirement Gathering

content:
ing forecasts based on historical data and market insights.

### Inventory Distribution Gap Analysis

### Christina and Kevin discussed the analysis of distribution gaps in inventory, focusing on metrics like micro rip gaps and the importance of tracking changes over time to understand service levels and forecasting accuracy. They explored the potential reasons behind gaps, such as inventory allocation, forecasting errors, or distributors not ordering due to stock availability. Christina explained the use of automated recommendations (Rec. Buys) to address gaps and improve inventory management, while Kevin raised questions about whether gaps solely indicate missed demand or if they should also consider the distributors' sales philosophy. They also discussed the possibility of adjusting gap metrics, such as focusing only on certain sizes, and agreed that the current approach of measuring gaps based on sales velocity and specific thresholds is reasonable.

metadata.title: Discovery & Requirement Gathering

content:
he current approach of measuring gaps based on sales velocity and specific thresholds is reasonable.

### Inventory Gaps and Forecast Review

### Kevin and Luis discussed inventory gaps and forecast issues, with Christina explaining that some gaps were due to delayed distributor orders and new SKUs only being added recently. They reviewed various reports, including a mail drops analysis that helps determine which products to discontinue based on sales performance and inventory liability. Kevin and Christina agreed to explore the liability PC report further in their next meeting.

### Anaplan Tool Discussion Planning Meeting

### Kevin and Christina scheduled a meeting for Friday morning to discuss the Anaplan tool and Christina's favorite reporting tool. They agreed to a one-hour session, with Christina noting she was busy next week but could accommodate it.

As Is Process - August 8/22 - Process and Mill (Luis & Christina, Kevin OOO)

As Is Process - Drop Mills Analysis - Aug 22nd
Process once a year: determine what to drop.
If dropping, it must include the entire style/color (all skus).
Check for the remaining assortment: if the remaining colors for a style is consistent.
(For example, dropping color=black makes sense?)

Drop wants to remove products with low sales and low inventory (on-hand)
Ideally, don’t want to have high liability (OnHand x PCAT)
PCAT: Price Category: price for sku/distributor
Cap: drop products not more than 4M or 5M USD a year

Data Risk & Gaps

- Lead Time and Case Packs

## Summary

### Strategic Agility in Data Systems

f major opportunities and improvements identified

## Summary

### Strategic Agility in Data Systems

### The team discussed Patrice's recent travel to Nicaragua, where she experienced cold weather and travel discomfort. They reviewed the status of a project, with Patrice noting that Marco had inquired about progress but hadn't provided clear feedback. Kevin and Luis presented their findings on the project, highlighting major opportunities and areas for improvement. Patrice emphasized the need for agile systems that can adapt to frequent business changes, as the company is good at tactical execution but lacks strategic agility in data systems. The team agreed to focus on creating a flexible solution that allows for quick execution while providing detailed insights.

### AI-Driven Inventory Forecasting Plan

metadata.title: Discovery & Requirement Gathering

content:
ows for quick execution while providing detailed insights.

### AI-Driven Inventory Forecasting Plan

### Luis presented a plan to improve inventory forecasting and supply network optimization using AI-driven recommendations. The team aims to automate daily forecast updates and generate distributor-specific models to better capture trends and reduce lost sales. Kevin shared metrics from a recent executive review showing an 8% reduction in lost sales and other improvements in product availability and revenue. The new system will focus on minimizing manual intervention while still allowing for user adjustments, with the goal of providing tailored forecasts for every distributor and product combination.

### Inventory Management Tool Enhancement

forecasts for every distributor and product combination.

### Inventory Management Tool Enhancement

### Luis presented a new forecasting and inventory management tool that will allow users to make manual adjustments while flagging significant gaps, lost sales, and excess inventory. The tool will feature alert review panels, prioritized by volume and ticket, and a control tower for a big picture view of sales and inventory. Patrice suggested making the dashboard more Bella-centric, with high-level gap rates and DC performance metrics, while also being able to filter for specific styles or products. The team agreed to further define the most critical metrics and views for regular use, particularly for Patrice's executive reviews with Marco and Norm.

### Customizing Inventory Forecasting System

metadata.title: Discovery & Requirement Gathering

y for Patrice's executive reviews with Marco and Norm.

### Customizing Inventory Forecasting System

### The team discussed a new inventory and forecasting system, with Luis explaining their plan to track distributor inventory gaps and reconstruct real demand using historical sales and inventory data. Patrice raised concerns about terminology differences between their business and Allo's, emphasizing that their distributor relationships are based on recommendations rather than direct control over inventory. The team agreed to customize the system to better align with their business model, with Kevin promising to provide example data showing how the system would handle significant stock gaps.

### Inventory Management Strategy Alignment

metadata.title: Discovery & Requirement Gathering

ing how the system would handle significant stock gaps.

### Inventory Management Strategy Alignment

### Patrice discussed the need for agility in inventory management, emphasizing the importance of aligning with distributors' inventory strategies rather than relying solely on the Anaplan system's recommendations. She proposed running parallel models to compare distributor forecasts with AI-driven forecasts, allowing for better understanding of sales impacts and inventory decisions. Patrice also highlighted the challenges of inventory overstocking due to economic uncertainty and tariffs, and stressed the need for better alignment with Marco and Norm on production levels to optimize supply chain and manufacturing processes.

### Distributor Forecast Analysis System

metadata.title: Discovery & Requirement Gathering

vels to optimize supply chain and manufacturing processes.

### Distributor Forecast Analysis System

### The team discussed the need for a flexible and agile approach to analyzing distributor forecasts, emphasizing the importance of being able to upload and compare distributor forecasts against internal projections. Patrice highlighted a specific case where a customer intentionally underforecasts sales, complicating inventory management. The group agreed on the necessity of developing a system that can quickly react to changes in distributor buy decisions, considering lead times and inventory carrying costs. Christina proposed customizing the system to better suit Bella Canvas's unique business needs, including creating a dedicated screen for distributor forecast analysis.

### Business Diversification and Market Shift

metadata.title: Discovery & Requirement Gathering

content:
a dedicated screen for distributor forecast analysis.

### Business Diversification and Market Shift

### Patrice discussed the changing dynamics of their business, highlighting the shift from distributors to direct accounts over the past four years, with distributors now comprising 80% of their business. She expressed a desire to reduce this dependency to 50% for better diversification, noting the impact of consolidations in the distributor market and the need for agility in forecasting and strategy. Patrice also mentioned efforts to expand into retail, including private label opportunities with Walmart and conversations with Hobby Lobby and Amazon, while acknowledging challenges like increased onboarding time for new customers and the need to adapt to changing market trends.

### SNS Acquisition Impact on Sales

metadata.title: Discovery & Requirement Gathering

content:
new customers and the need to adapt to changing market trends.

### SNS Acquisition Impact on Sales

### Patrice discussed the impact of SNS's acquisition of Alpha Broder on sales, noting that while SNS's market share increased, it did not reach the level expected. He highlighted the challenge of tracking changes in direct sales due to the large number of accounts, suggesting that some Alpha Broder customers may have shifted to direct purchases. Christina and Kevin agreed that more attention should be paid to direct sales metrics and infrastructure, as this area is currently underdeveloped compared to distributor reporting.

### Enhancing Planning and Forecasting Systems

### The team discussed challenges with their current planning and reporting systems, particularly focusing on Anaplan's limitations. Christina explained that Anaplan, while effective once set up, lacks agility and requires extensive steps for even minor changes, while also having issues with code visibility and frequent sign-out requirements. The team identified opportunities to improve their forecasting process, with Christina noting that breaking down the weekly forecast into daily updates could significantly reduce time consumption and enable more frequent buy updates.

### Understanding Anaplan Forecast Methods

metadata.title: Discovery & Requirement Gathering

content:
e time consumption and enable more frequent buy updates.

### Understanding Anaplan Forecast Methods

### Christina explained the outlier screen, which uses different mathematical forecast methods to identify items not within the bounds of the higher and lower bounds, and noted that her team reviewed it. She described the stat forecast, which includes active and phased-out items, and explained how they manually override forecasts and use Anaplan's recommended 12-month forecast base for new items. Christina also explained the various forecast methods, noting that Anaplan selects the method with the least error, and mentioned that she has a background in applied math, which helps her understand these concepts.

### Sales Forecasting Process Overview

metadata.title: Discovery & Requirement Gathering

content:
in applied math, which helps her understand these concepts.

### Sales Forecasting Process Overview

### Christina explained the process of forecasting sales using statistical methods and discussed how to handle new products with less than 12 months of history. She demonstrated how to assign similar styles to new items and provide volume forecasts. The team reviewed the full forecast of 98 million units, which includes all active, new, and phase-out items across various channels. Christina also showed how to override top-level forecasts and adjust channel distribution percentages as needed.

### Anaplan Forecasting System Streamlining

and adjust channel distribution percentages as needed.

### Anaplan Forecasting System Streamlining

### Christina demonstrated the complex Anaplan forecasting system, highlighting that it requires jumping between multiple screens and involves significant manual work to fix forecast errors and configure size curves. She expressed a desire to streamline the process, noting that the current system takes too much time and effort away from analysis. The team discussed the need to simplify the forecast process and integrate it directly into the buy system, with Christina planning to coordinate with Grant Thornton on the new forecast approach. Patrice inquired about the data flow timeline, which Christina said she would confirm with Supretha.

### Anaplan Forecast Integration Strategy

### The team discussed the integration of forecasts into Anaplan, with Christina confirming that the forecast should feed into Anaplan to inform buy decisions, following a "crawl, walk, run" approach. Patrice explained the role of markers in optimizing production based on buy ratios and demand, highlighting Anaplan's functionality in managing marker libraries but noting its limitations in forecast and replenishment planning. ### Anaplan Buy Feeding Strategy

### The team discussed the importance of producing and feeding buys to Anaplan, with Patrice emphasizing the need to focus on demand trends, especially for Algo's exponential growth and Bell Canvas's trajectory. They highlighted the significance of shipment forecasts and the impact of consolidated inventory, noting that Anaplan's model considers both POS and shipment trends. Patrice suggested having a conversation with the Anaplan team to incorporate shipment trends into their current model, as seen in the significant gap between POS and shipment trends for S&S.

They explored the potential for optimizing production and inventory management by leveraging Anaplan and other tools, with Patrice emphasizing the need for better alerts on changing trends and opportunities to slow down or cancel production. ### Distributor Network Mapping Discussion

### Luis discussed the network structure for forecasting distributor item combinations and clarified that they only need a warehouse-to-distributor mapping, not a distributor-to-store mapping, as they can reconstruct store demand from POS daily history data. Patrice confirmed that the warehouse-to-distributor mapping would need to be agile due to ongoing DC strategy discussions, including potential regional moves. The team clarified terminology around "store" versus "Distributor DC," with Christina and Patrice agreeing that "store" should refer to the fulfillment locations where customer demand is served.

Luis and Patrice clarified that while they can map data up to the distributor DC level, they don't have access to the subsequent layer of customer data due to competitive concerns. Luis concluded he would work with the network and forecast model using available data at the DC level to produce forecasts.

### Forecasting System Overview and Updates

### Supriya explained the current forecasting process for Direct, noting that it was originally set up when Direct was smaller but has since grown. She walked through the system's dashboard, showing how data flows from the data hub model into different models for demand planning and production planning. Supriya demonstrated how the team can edit forecasts at both the style-color level and the monthly level, with the final forecast pushing down to subsequent pages. Kevin inquired about the ability to edit forecasts, and Supriya confirmed that edits can be made to both the style-color list and the monthly boxes, with changes propagating through the system.

### Sales Data Disaggregation and Forecasting

### Supriya explained the process of disaggregating sales data from a channel level down to a distributor and SKU level, which is used to create a shipment forecast. She described how the forecast is then used to recommend a buy, taking into account factors like inventory position and multi-echelon logic. Kevin asked about the difference between the shipment forecast and the buy, and Supriya clarified that while the shipment forecast shows expected shipments to distributors, the actual buy is based on DC-level requirements and considers global inventory levels.

### Closing the Shipment Data Gap

### Patrice and Supriya discussed the discrepancy between POS and shipment data, noting a significant gap of over 50% in shipments compared to previous expectations of a 20-30% decrease. They emphasized the need to analyze shipment trends and incorporate predictive analytics to better align inventory levels with actual distributor behavior, as current forecasting is heavily reliant on POS data. Supriya highlighted the challenges in forecasting shipments due to their variability, but expressed optimism about using AI technology to improve predictive capabilities. The team agreed to explore additional data points and AI tools to enhance business decision-making, particularly in light of distributors' lack of transparency.

## Summary

### Data Flow and Design Review

### The team discussed the status of data flowing and reviewed the design layout, with Patrice planning to send Marco a recap of their progress. Christina confirmed that the data was indeed flowing, and the team planned to focus on key sections of the solution design to ensure everyone was on the right track. Kevin mentioned that Luis had captured the discussions from the past week and a half, and the goal was to provide an initial pulse check to ensure alignment before any sign-offs.

### Europe Distributor Forecast Design Review

metadata.title: Discovery & Requirement Gathering

content:
pulse check to ensure alignment before any sign-offs.

### Europe Distributor Forecast Design Review

### Luis presented a draft solution design document to Patrice and Christina, which included Christina's previous comments. They discussed the scope of the project, focusing on producing forecasts for distributors in direct Europe and handling inventory management at a granular level. Patrice confirmed that COGS would not be included in the scope, and Christina agreed to remove that from the document. The team also reviewed the features of the forecast model, including the ability to identify hot or cold products and generate recommended inventory levels.

### Inventory Allotment and Reporting Process

metadata.title: Discovery & Requirement Gathering

content:
d products and generate recommended inventory levels.

### Inventory Allotment and Reporting Process

### The team discussed inventory management and allocation processes, clarifying that they would use the term "allotment" instead of "allocation" to describe the planning of inventory transfers between warehouses and distributors based on forecasts and distributor demands. Luis explained that the system would produce reports highlighting critical inventory gaps, stockouts, and recommended buys, with the ability to customize store clustering for forecasting purposes. Patrice raised a question about the timing for data input, and Christina confirmed that the agreed time for dropping data on Azure Blob was 2:30 PM Central, with processing completed by 3 PM.

### Data Processing Job Scheduling

metadata.title: Discovery & Requirement Gathering

content:
ure Blob was 2:30 PM Central, with processing completed by 3 PM.

### Data Processing Job Scheduling

### The team discussed the scheduling of data processing jobs, with Christina explaining that most data is processed at 2 AM PST, while POS data requires a separate job at 9 AM PST due to its different timing from distributor data. Luis mentioned that the output files still need to be finalized, with Kevin taking responsibility to follow up on the format requirements. The team also briefly touched on plans for handling data for three warehouses and distributors, though this point was left somewhat unclear.

### Supply Network and Forecasting Updates

metadata.title: Discovery & Requirement Gathering

content:
stributors, though this point was left somewhat unclear.

### Supply Network and Forecasting Updates

### The team discussed including Europe (BE and UK) in their supply network mapping, with Patrice emphasizing the need for system agility to accommodate potential changes, including a planned move to a centralized DC in Texas by 2026-2027. Luis confirmed that the system can easily adjust to changes in DC locations and network mappings. They agreed to handle four product statuses (new, active, phased out, and obsolete) for forecasting, with Patrice noting that phase-outs should have forecasted sales but no purchases. Luis also clarified that they would provide a 52-week forecast horizon with weekly buckets.

### 24-Month Forecast System Discussion

metadata.title: Discovery & Requirement Gathering

content:
uld provide a 52-week forecast horizon with weekly buckets.

### 24-Month Forecast System Discussion

### The team discussed generating a 24-month forecast, with Luis agreeing to confirm this approach. Patrice raised concerns about Anaplan's monthly period-based functionality, but Luis clarified that weekly data would still be acceptable. Luis explained that the system would automatically correct for lost sales and include a UI screen for future forecast editing, allowing adjustments for external factors like promotions or weather. He also noted that new products without historical sales data would not generate forecasts.

### Forecast Mapping and System Updates

metadata.title: Discovery & Requirement Gathering

content:
without historical sales data would not generate forecasts.

### Forecast Mapping and System Updates

### The team discussed forecast mapping and configuration for distributor and direct channels, with Christina proposing a regional grouping structure for forecasts. Luis explained the forecast engine's capabilities, including safety stock management and inventory allocation logic. Patrice raised concerns about using POS forecasts instead of shipment forecasts, which Kevin and Luis agreed to address. The team reviewed a new UDA (User Defined Attributes) system for flexible data grouping, with Christina planning to work with Roshin to finalize the mapping logic. The implementation is still targeting Q1 for go-live, with Christina and Patrice requesting a live demo of the system soon.

Allocation Statuses (Column Y-AC in Open Orders):

- Allocated B: Back-order beyond 30 days (customer).
- Allocated N: Reserved for back orders (customer).
- Allocated S: Allocated and committed to an order - most likely going to ship ("allocation sort order logic" algorithm determines first allocation and customers).Note: "S" also means Hold/Reservation (placed by BC for operational purposes, e.g., catching transfers from Nicaragua, Bella Canvas General Pop Inventory managed by Inventory Team).
- Allocated U: Open stock, not tied to order.
- C: Confirmed regular customer orders (once order is confirmed and within 30 days of shipments, 'S' converts to 'C').

## Bella+Canvas Distribution Network and System Summary

The Bella+Canvas supply chain is a hybrid, multi-echelon network that balances centralized manufacturing with a complex, tiered distribution model across the US, Canada, and Europe. The network is undergoing changes to improve strategic agility and efficiency.

### 1. Supply Chain and Manufacturing Configuration

- Manufacturing Origin: Goods originate from a manufacturing center in Nicaragua (NI). The majority of garments are cut and dyed in the USA, specifically in Los Angeles, California.
- Warehouses (DCs): Bella+Canvas utilizes three warehouses for distribution: Nicaragua (NI), Maryland (MD), and Nevada (NV).Consolidation: The company is planning a DC consolidation, moving the Nevada operations to Maryland by 2026–2027.
- Inventory Flow: Shipments to distributors are essentially transfers from these warehouses, and the Invent solution needs to forecast these shipment needs (Sell-In).

### 2. Distribution Channels and Tiers

metadata.title: Distribution Network

content:
t solution needs to forecast these shipment needs (Sell-In).

### 2. Distribution Channels and Tiers

Bella+Canvas primarily operates through two channels: Distributor (wholesale) and Direct (including e-commerce and retail).

content: - Distributor Channel (Wholesale): This is the dominant revenue stream, comprising about 80% of the business (though the company aims to reduce this dependency to 50% for diversification).Structure: Bella+Canvas works with 13+ distributors. Distributors are classified into three tiers based on sales volume (the below tiers are future state to be aggregated in INVENT) Gold Tier: Represents 75% of the volume.Silver Tier: Represents the next 15% of the volume.Bronze Tier: Represents the remainder.Data Sharing: Distributors generally do not share Store detail data with Bella+Canvas, only sales quantities, stock sold, on hand, and on order by store and item.

metadata.title: Distribution Network

content:
data with Bella+Canvas, only sales quantities, stock sold, on hand, and on order by store and item.
- Direct Channel: This segment is growing and includes e-commerce, craft retailers, and white glove accounts.Forecasting: For the Direct Channel, forecasting is done by clusters (Gold/Silver/Bronze) defined by Bella+Canvas based on sales volume and region. Gold-tier direct customers have individual item/month forecasts, while Silver and Bronze clusters have an aggregated forecast.

### 3. Current Planning and System Challenges

The current system relies on internal planning tools (primarily Anaplan and Excel) but faces challenges in scaling to meet the complexity of the network:

metadata.title: Distribution Network

content:
(primarily Anaplan and Excel) but faces challenges in scaling to meet the complexity of the network:

- Manual Effort: The generation of Recommended Buys and the entire forecasting process is monthly and highly manual, taking days of focused work.
- Forecasting Limitations: The current planning system treats outliers globally and fails to capture distributor-specific trends or demand spikes.
- Lack of Lost Sales Visibility: There is no automated process to track sales velocity or calculate lost sales opportunities due to inventory shortages, requiring manual analysis.
- Inventory Alignment: Challenges exist in aligning internal forecasts with distributor forecasts due to limited contractual obligations and varying inventory strategies.

### 4. Invent Solution Integration

The Invent system is designed to provide AI-driven visibility and automation across the supply network:

metadata.title: Distribution Network

content:
Invent system is designed to provide AI-driven visibility and automation across the supply network:

- AI-Driven Forecasting: Invent will generate AI-automated, distributor-product tailored forecasts and then use this data to generate recommended buys (Sell-In) from the warehouse to the Distributor Stores.
- Inventory Visibility: The system will provide a dedicated Control Tower and DC Replenishment Orders screen with visibility into key metrics like Target Detail, DC Inventory (On Hand, In-Transit), and Days of Supply.
- Replenishment Logic: The system will calculate optimal inventory target levels (cover period forecast + safety stock) and generate orders based on inventory eligibility, lead times, and configurable safety stock/target parameters.

metadata.title: Distribution Network

content:
The Invent project is focused on transforming Bella+Canvas's demand forecasting and buy processes from a manual, generalized approach into an automated, data-driven, and highly granular system.

---

### 1. Current State (As-Is) Process and Challenges

The current process is manual, time-consuming, and limited by the capabilities of existing planning tools like Anaplan and Excel.

#### A. Current Forecasting and Buy Process

- Process Cycle: Forecasting is a monthly process.
- Input Data: The process starts with Historical Sales Data and is used to generate a baseline Forecast.
- Manual Intervention: The output is then subjected to Manual Forecast Adjustments, which requires human review and setting of bounds.
- Time Commitment: The manual work takes +2 days of focused effort.
- Buy Recommendations: The resulting Final NTM Forecast feeds into the generation of Recommended Buys, which is also a manual process.

#### B. Systemic Gaps (Anaplan Limitations)

metadata.title: Forecast

content:
on of Recommended Buys, which is also a manual process.

#### B. Systemic Gaps (Anaplan Limitations)

The current tools struggle to manage Bella+Canvas's complex distribution network, leading to subjective and less accurate forecasts:

- Outlier Analysis: The system treats outliers globally rather than by specific distributor or channel.
- Distributor Trends: It fails to capture unique trends, seasonality, or demand spikes for individual distributors.
- Lost Sales Analysis: It does not automatically track sales velocity or analyze missed opportunities due to inventory shortages, requiring manual gap analysis.
- Error Risk: The reliance on manual files makes the process subject to involuntary errors.

#### C. Visibility Limitations

The current process provides limited visibility into critical real-time inventory and performance metrics:

- Weeks on Stock (WOS)
- Available to Sell (ATS) vs. Safety Stock
- Hot Items and Cold Items
- Sales Velocity

---

metadata.title: Forecast

content:
ck (WOS)
- Available to Sell (ATS) vs. Safety Stock
- Hot Items and Cold Items
- Sales Velocity

---

### 2. Gaps and Future Opportunities (To-Be)

The Invent solution addresses the lack of automation and granular analysis to improve accuracy, efficiency, and inventory optimization.

#### A. Automation and Efficiency

- Zero Manual Work: The goal for the core forecasting process is 0 days of manual work, enabled by Automated Data Pipelines.
- AI-Driven Forecasting: AI-Automated Forecasts will be updated every day.
- Automated Buys: Recommended Buys will be generated automatically based on the AI-driven forecast.
- Faster Cycles: The solution is designed to reduce cycles and execute faster.

#### B. Forecasting Accuracy and Granularity

metadata.title: Forecast

content:
ution is designed to reduce cycles and execute faster.

#### B. Forecasting Accuracy and Granularity

- Tailored Forecasts: Models will be Distributor – Product tailored for every distributor/product combination, capturing sales behavior more closely.
- Lost Sales Calculation: The system will automatically calculate lost sales and use demand reconstruction to provide a more accurate forecast.
- Granular Analysis: The system will enable more granular data analysis on distributor-level trends.
- Predictive Analysis: Develop predictive analysis for phase-out items to anticipate sales decline and liability impact.

#### C. Strategic Visibility and Optimization

metadata.title: Forecast

content:
ems to anticipate sales decline and liability impact.

#### C. Strategic Visibility and Optimization

- Improved Visibility: Provide intuitive graphic modules to compare sales history vs. forecasted units in modules like the Control Tower and Forecast Review & Edit.
- Inventory Optimization: The system will focus on optimizing inventory levels to achieve Lower Lost Sales and Lower Excess Inventory.
- Alerting System: Implement an Alert Review module to prioritize and flag exceptions for Gaps, stockouts, WOS, and trends.
- Clear Metrics: Establish clearer metrics and verbiage for calculating distributor inventory requirements and improving alignment.

| Category | Feature/Metric | Granularity/Level | Logic/Time Horizon | Output Format |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Forecasting | Model Type | Distributor/Item Level | AI learning and statistical models | CSV |
| Forecasting | Demand Type | Sell-Out Demand | Corrects for lost sales (Demand Reconstruction) | CSV |
| Forecasting | Frequency | Daily | Updated every day using latest sales/inventory data | CSV |
| Forecasting | Horizon | Weekly buckets | 2 year horizon (Initial) | CSV |
| Forecasting | Distributor Aggregation | Distributor/Item Level | Forecast represents the aggregated demand of all stores served by the distributor | N/A |
| Forecasting | Direct Channel Tiers | Clusters/Individual | Forecast generated for Direct channel. Specific aggregation tiers (Gold/Silver/Bronze) apply. | N/A |
| Ordering / Replenishment | Core Process | Warehouse to Distributor (Sell-In) | "No-touch" or "low-touch" automated recommendations | CSV (for "Release Orders") |

content:
butor (Sell-In) | "No-touch" or "low-touch" automated recommendations | CSV (for "Release Orders") |
| Ordering / Replenishment | Target Level | Distributor/Item/Size Level | Sum of Cover Period Forecast (min 14 days) + Safety Stock | CSV (for "Release Orders") |
| Ordering / Replenishment | Safety Stock (SS) | Configurable by Service Level (SL) | SS based on SL (Initial 93% target) and weekly review period | N/A |
| Ordering / Replenishment | Prioritization | Per Store/Distributor | Prioritizes orders for stores with greatest statistical probability for maximum profit (limited stock) | N/A |
| Data Mapping | Distributor Store Data | SKU/Store/Date | Distributors share sales quantities, stock sold, on hand, on order by store and item. | N/A |
| Data Mapping | Network Mapping | Warehouse-to-Distributor DC | Invent reconstructs demand from POS data without needing distributor-to-store mapping. | N/A |

| Reporting / KPIs | Alerts | Exceptions (High, Medium, Critical) | Flags Gaps, stockouts, WOS, trends, Missing Lead Time, Zero Sales Forecast | UI/Alert Review Screen |
